message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and findings suggest gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Without treatment, long-standing GERD can lead to the development of esophageal stricture due to chronic inflammation and scarring of the esophageal lining. Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma can also be a complication of GERD, but it usually takes years to develop. Sliding hiatal hernia and pyloric stenosis are unlikely complications of GERD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest that the patient has gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Without treatment, the patient is at greatest risk for developing esophageal strictures due to chronic inflammation and tissue damage. Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma is a potential long-term complication of GERD, but it typically develops after years of untreated acid reflux. Sliding hiatal hernia can contribute to GERD symptoms but is not a complication of the health condition. Pyloric stenosis is not related to GERD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the findings on esophagogastroduodenoscopy suggest gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Without treatment, the patient is at greatest risk for developing an esophageal stricture due to repeated damage to the esophagus from the acid reflux. Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma is a possible complication of GERD, but it usually takes years or even decades to develop. Sliding hiatal hernia and pyloric stenosis are not typical complications of GERD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest GERD, which can lead to esophageal stricture if left untreated. Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma also has a strong association with GERD, but this would take years to develop. Sliding hiatal hernia can be a cause of GERD, but it is not a complication of GERD itself. Pyloric stenosis is not related to GERD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest reflux esophagitis, which can lead to esophageal stricture if left untreated. Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma is a complication of chronic acid reflux but takes many years to develop. Sliding hiatal hernia is a common finding in patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease but does not have an increased risk for complications. Pyloric stenosis occurs at the outlet of the stomach and is not related to reflux or esophageal symptoms.

Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma is a potential long-term complication of GERD, but it takes years to develop. Sliding hiatal hernia and pyloric stenosis are not directly related to GERD.

Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma is a rare complication but can occur with long-term untreated GERD. Sliding hiatal hernia and pyloric stenosis are not typical complications of GERD.

Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma can also be a complication of GERD, but it takes longer to develop. Sliding hiatal hernia and pyloric stenosis are not direct complications of GERD.

Without treatment, the patient is at greatest risk for developing esophageal stricture, which is a narrowing of the esophagus caused by scarring from the erosions. Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma is a long-term complication of GERD, but it usually takes years to develop. Sliding hiatal hernia and pyloric stenosis are not complications of GERD.
